subject: rain, rain go away
event:
It rained in Santa Fe yesterday afternoon.  At least on the north side of town.

"Rain" is a bit of an understatement, though.  The water fell in blinding sheets, alternating with hail.  Hailstones piled up on the ground like styrofoam peanuts, forming ankle-deep white drifts.  The streets turned into rivers, and lakes formed in some of the intersections.  We had cars stalling out on Alameda when they tried to drive through waters that came halfway up their tires.

And of course our roofs sprung leaks.  Minor leaks in the main house with its new pitched roofs, where the violence of the storm forced water in through vents and such.  Major leaks in the office house, which is partially torn down as my new book tower is constructed, and has an old flat roof over the parts not torn down.  The hole that will eventually be my basement is now a swimming pool.  And the worse leak of all, of course, was in back closet where some valuable books and comics were being stormed.  Half of my remainining stock of the now out-of-print Guardians of Order GAME OF THRONE rpg suffered water damage, to a greater or lesser degree.  We caught it early enough to rescue the rest of the stock, thankfully, but some of the books are still ruined, and the carpet in that room is soggy and already beginning to molder and will need to be ripped up.

A real mess.

I blame Parris.  For years now she's been teaching her Irish godchildren to chant, "Rain, rain go away, go and rain on Santa Fe."  The gods must have been listening.

props.current_music: A Hard Rain's A Goin' to Fall

comments.article:
ACK!
You have my sympathies sir.

lo siento para su lío desconcertante

It's been a terrible for year for weather all across the country.
From 35°C dry heat (what is it in fahrenheit, 100 or so?), I feel for you :)
That's terrible. I'm so sorry, George.

I go to Saint John's College in Annapolis Maryland and our branch campus is in your lovely town. School is starting and a few of my closest friends transferred out there this year. I imagine it was a welcoming present to them.
You have not had our rain George, we have had the worst rain in decades with flooding all over the country....I'd blame the yankees ;-)

So sorry to hear about you aqua-troubles. There are, however, those of us that would still pay good money for a water damaged copy of the rpg. ;-P

I'm just glad it wasn't one of the lovely tornados we get here in Oklahoma. We would all drown in lakes of sorrow if one of those blew through and ran off with your computer.
Yes, I suppose I'll have a "water damage sale" at some point.  Those were hundred dollar limited editions before the leak.  Now... well, I'll need to assess the damage, copy by copy.
comments.subject: water damaged books

comments.article:
Oh, no - sorry to hear this. Hope I'm right that it sounds like the new roof in the main house held at least, even if the water managed to sneak in another way. Looks like instead of being able to bury someone in the hole at the office house you'll have to find a body "accidentally" floating in the pool.

Hope you don't find anything else damaged. Hang in there.

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: ethelclose
comments.article: Sorry to hear this, George. At least the new roof held, right? Good luck and extort some comfort from the cat.

comments.upictitle: Rum, Sodomy, and the Lash: Pick Two: monkey pirate
comments.article: In an odd bit of synchronicity, the AC unit where I work, here in arid Los Angeles, blew out this morning, flooding our server room. That's two floods in a desert in one day. I'm sure that's significant of something.
that is a crappy search and recover mission, been there done that. Hoping for the best for you all.
comments.subject: oh, I'm so sorry

comments.article: Oh, gods, that sucks!

Ugh. No good, at all.

Will the basement need to be pumped? I'm not sure how the desert ground absorbs water, living in ol' subtropical Houston and all.

Oh man, thats terrible.

Thankfully, my mother always ended that rhyme with "come again another day", so you didnt have my family adding to your woes!
That's terrible, I'm so sorry. I never dreamed you got such weather in Santa Fe?!?!?
Sorry for your aqua troubles, George. I'd love a water-logged edition! :)
comments.subject: La Lluvia

comments.upictitle: OMG, it's a talking biscuit named Mara!: Nature-Redwood path
comments.article:
The gods must have been listening.

Either that or it's my dad :)

His memorial is next weekend, outside of Santa Fe (he wanted his ashes scattered where he used to pick mushrooms, at about 9,000 feet, and it's only accessible in August)...and I'm not going to be able to be there.

If youbdont already have a roofer that you like, may I recommend one? Leroy Ortiz is a licensed roofer with at least 20 years experience, and I've been very happy with his work and his prices.

505-877-9510
Ouch. That really hurts. Particularly to hear about the RPG books suffering so. Those are beautiful books. I still have mine wrapped in two sheets of plastic just in case something like that happens.

Santa Fe is in the Mountains, semi-arid at worst but not a real desert.

George is living in the mountains during monsoon time, of course it's going to rain more there.

A signature is worth a thousand bucks.
comments.subject: Nitpicking

comments.article:
A basement swimming pool? Sweet! :p

Although actually the book tower sounds better yet. I want one of those. (And I don't mean the leaning tower of books in my bedroom, threatening to topple at any time...)

And the worse leak of all, of course, was in back closet where some valuable books and comics were being stormed.

Miserable times, lovely quote.
Winter is coming.

Here in my country we get many rains. I know when you get much wet. This will cause you much work. You will not write when you must do other thing. So many other things and you will not write. I am sorry.
comments.subject: My sorry for your water flood
